passages.text: We co- hosted the Stock Exchange of Thailand's flagship annual conference under the theme "Beyond the Challenges" featuring panelists from government executives, policy makers, the private sector, as well as corporate private and group meetings. We provide key takeaways below.

Competitiveness, capital market reforms, and household debt were the key discussion topics in the plenary sessions. On the country's competitiveness, the Board of Investment (BOI) highlighted Thailand's current strengths on infrastructure (energy & digital readiness), FTAs, STEM talents, and tax incentives. CP Group and Huawei echoed strong demand for data center investment and digital services in Thailand. Although tariffs and trans- shipment are ongoing, they see this as an opportunity to rebalance local supply chains. Regulators are trying to improve investor confidence in capital markets by focusing on better governance, stronger surveillance, and more consistent enforcement, as well as promoting tax- saving funds and mandatory provident funds to support long- term participation. Addressing household debt requires both short- term and long- term strategies as interest rate cuts alone cannot solve the problem. In the near term, the panelists discussed that targeted measures such as expanding the capacity of AMCs, offering soft loans, and providing regulatory flexibility can help restructure distressed debt.

To achieve high value- added tourism, Thai Airways highlighted fleet optimization strategies by leveraging Thailand as a regional hub to focus on Asia- Pacific destinations with more connecting flights and fuel- efficient narrow- body aircraft fleets. Agoda consistently saw Thailand among top destinations with growth opportunity in sustainable and wellness tourism. Health tech, although at an early stage, has a promising growth potential with the call for more regulatory support from experts. Virtual banks should not aggravate the household debt problem, but rather improve financial inclusion, according to the CFO of SCB X. Initial success would result in improving innovation, inclusion, and banking cost efficiency.

See inside for takeaways from corporate sessions of Thailand Focus Day 1. The companies participating included Advanced Info Service (ADVANC), Central Pattana (CPN), Global Power Synergy (GPSC), PTT Oil and Retail (OR), Plan B Media (PLANB), PTT Global Chemical (PTGC), Thai Oil (TOP), WHA Corp (WHA), Berli Jucker (BJC, Not Rated), Dohome (DOHOME, Not Rated), and Srisawad Corp (SAWAD, Not Rated).

BofA Securities participated in the preparation of this report, in part, based on information provided by Kiatnakin Bhata Securities Public Company Limited (Kiatnakin Bhata Securities). Dr. Paopoom Rojanasakul, Deputy Minister of Finance gave his keynote at the Thailand Focus and emphasized aligning economic policy with dynamic global markets while addressing long- term challenges. He stressed that policy design must consider global uncertainties such as geopolitical tensions, technological shifts, and climate risks.

He believed that Thailand's economy is expanding moderately, with stronger- than- expected momentum in the first half of 2025. The Ministry of Finance projects GDP growth at \(2.2\%\) for 2025, with potential for upward revision. Exports are rebounding, led by electronics, while tourism has normalized with higher per- capita spending, particularly in wellness and premium segments. Fundamentals remain sound with ample reserves, low public debt, and a resilient banking sector. Monetary conditions are easing following policy rate cuts, supporting credit expansion. Trade outcomes include a negotiated \(19\%\) US tariff on Thai goods, benefiting exporters, while a new quota and rule- of- origin measures aim to protect domestic industries and encourage Thai firms to invest abroad.

He posited capital market reform is anchored on four pillars: demand, supply, rules, and technology, aiming for deeper, fairer, faster, and globally connected markets. On the demand side, tax incentives for retirement and ESG funds are expected to boost domestic liquidity. On the supply side, innovative products such as sustainable- linked bonds and green bonds are expanding opportunities. Regulatory reforms are modernizing the Securities and Exchange Act with greater digital adoption, while technology partnerships, including with Nasdaq, strengthen transparency and oversight, particularly around high- frequency trading (HFT) and short- selling.

The government also positioned Thailand as a forward- looking financial hub by fostering innovation, improving investor confidence, and enhancing payment systems. Initiatives include the launch of "Tourist DigiPay," which allows foreign visitors to convert digital assets into baht, and the introduction of "G Token" to fund public projects. With robust investment applications reaching a record 2,000 projects, strong foreign participation, and data centers boosting digital and AI capacity, Thailand aims to sustain competitiveness, attract global investors, and build long- term resilience.

The BOI reported strong investment momentum in Investment applications reached a ten- year high last year at more than one trillion baht (US\\$34bn), a \(35\%\) increase from 2023. Foreign direct investment also rose \(25\%\) . In the first half of this year, applications exceeded US\\$32bn, up \(139\%\) from the same period last year. Top FDI sources were Singapore, China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Japan, with electronics, digital, and automotive as key sectors.

Thailand's physical and digital infrastructure was emphasized. The country has deep seaports, international airports, and more than 70 industrial estates. It also has a developed digital infrastructure and top- tier data centers. On market access, Thailand has 17 FTAs with 24 countries, is a member of The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), and is accelerating talks with the EU, Canada, and Korea.

Supply chains were described as robust in automotive, electronics, and chemicals. These supply chains support new industries such as EVs, semiconductors, and advanced electronics. Energy readiness is part of the pitch. Thailand is launching a Utility Green Tariff (UGT) with renewable energy certificates and offers direct Power Purchase Agreements (PPAs). The government has allocated 2,000 megawatts specifically for data center needs.

Talent and facilitation measures were also highlighted. Thailand produces at least 100,000 STEM graduates per year, and the BOI is working with the education ministries on programs for semiconductors, EVs, and AI. The BOI offers tax and non- tax incentives and uses a competitiveness fund. A one- stop Thailand Investment & Expat Service Center opened in March at One Bangkok for visas, work permits, and investment consultations. A long- term resident visa offers 10 years with a digital work permit for four target groups. Rankings cited included the U.S. News "best country to start a business," Kearney's FDI Confidence Index (No. 1 in ASEAN, No. 10 globally), No. 1 in ASEAN on the SDG Index, and No. 6 worldwide for expat destinations.

CP Group continues to invest around US\\$1bn annually in its core businesses which are telecom and retail. The company anticipates increasing data center investment in Thailand due to its strategic location and incentives, positioning it as a key hub for ASEAN and Asia in an AI- driven economy. The Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) is transitioning from petrochemicals to new manufacturing and data centers, with strong telecom infrastructure. Incentives for expats such as long- term visas and 99- year foreign land ownership which could attract more people and capital, emphasizing that Thailand is on the right track despite global uncertainties.

Huawei sees government initiatives (e.g., EEC, Thailand 4.0, and Cloud- First policies) as supportive signals but also acknowledges gaps in skills and in the readiness of modern digital infrastructure. It emphasized the needs of building a local ecosystem and sustained R&D. Huawei typically invests about \(20 - 25\%\) of revenue into R&D on average. It also pointed to the power needs of AI data centers and the resulting opportunity in green energy. Over the past five years, Huawei has trained 100,000 IT professionals in Thailand to help transfer technology and retain skills locally.

On tariffs, the BOI framed the situation as a long- term game. The readjustment of tariffs can happen at any time. Since ASEAN tariff levels are broadly similar (around 19- 20%), the differentiators will be economic fundamentals and what each country offers to investors. Thailand's pitch remains infrastructure, supply chains, workforce quality, energy readiness (including clean energy), and cost- effective manufacturing.

The details of any trans- shipment tariff are still under negotiation. Definitions and scope are pending. Thailand's team, led by the deputy prime minister, is working to secure an outcome that benefits investors in Thailand. Meanwhile, the BOI sees an opportunity to strengthen localization and will focus on supply- chain development to raise local content.

From CP Group's agricultural perspective, the immediate tariff implications relate to raw materials like corn and wheat. Thailand has historically imported these mostly from South America and parts of Eastern Europe. A shift toward US supplies could still be cost- competitive and may even reduce input costs for feed and poultry. At the same time, there is a need to support domestic soybean and corn farmers during the transition and to modernize plantations with better technology and management.

The BOI outlined measures to help existing investors adapt. A "smart and sustainable industry" measure supports upgrades such as replacing machinery and adopting automation, digital tools, and AI to raise efficiency. A new program promotes localization, especially for EVs and electrical appliances, by giving additional incentives to firms that reach set local- content thresholds.

To build links between global investors and local firms, the BOI is supporting events and programs. Examples include the annual Subcon Thailand subcontracting and business- matching event and sourcing- day partnerships. These aim to deepen local supply chains and help companies meet localization goals.

The CP Group prioritized talent. The speaker urged making Thailand a hub for talent- bringing people to live, work, and do business, while upskilling local workers. The company also called for political stability, noting current issues with a neighbor are manageable. CP stressed connectivity and logistics across mainland ASEAN- connecting China, Thailand, Malaysia, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam, and Myanmar- and regulatory focus to make Thailand valuable to ASEAN, China, and the U.S.

Sector priorities included tourism and agriculture. The speaker suggested transforming agriculture through cooperative structures over a three- to five- year journey. He linked this to a broader push for digital transformation and renewable energy. The goal is to move toward a green economy and position Thailand as a leading country in that transition.

Speakers agreed that investment interest shows continued confidence in Thailand. The country is positioning itself as a datacenter and Al- support hub for the region. Strong physical and digital infrastructure, market access through FTAs and The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), and energy programs that include green options are part of the appeal.

Global risks, including tariffs and tech tensions, are real but viewed as manageable. The BOI and private sector both see these as opportunities to accelerate modernization, invest in efficiency, and increase local content. Negotiations on trans- shipment rules are ongoing, and the aim is to secure outcomes supportive of investors in Thailand.

Talent is the main challenge raised by multiple speakers. The solution proposed is two- track: attract international talent and rapidly develop local skills, especially in semiconductors, EVs, Al, and digital technologies. Policy tools such as long- term visas, one- stop investment and expat services, and targeted education programs are already in use.

Finally, the path forward centers on execution. Priorities include supply- chain localization, industry upgrades using automation and Al, regional logistics connectivity, and energy frameworks that match the rising power needs of digital infrastructure. Huawei also highlighted sovereign cloud, sovereign data centers, and data- platform readiness as important next steps for secure, competitive growth.

Thailand's capital markets face weakening liquidity, falling from a \(46\%\) regional trading share to around \(23\%\) by mid- 2025. The panel identified the causes as insufficient new capital inflows, fragmented savings channels, inconsistent trading rules, and governance concerns. Short- term pressures, such as large LTF redemptions, have further undermined investor confidence and activity.

In response, regulators and the exchange have raised listing standards, tightened disclosure, embedded ESG practices, and launched savings schemes like Vayupak Fund and ESGX. Enforcement is being strengthened through stricter oversight of auditors and advisors, new digital and Al surveillance tools, and legal reforms to expand powers. Meanwhile, the exchange committed to pause further market- mechanism changes to restore stability, while asset managers and institutions, like the Government Pension Fund (GPF), are adapting strategies to support long- term participation.

Looking forward, structural solutions center on broadening domestic demand through a mandatory provident fund and individual savings accounts to channel household wealth into capital markets. Panelists agreed that stable rules, stronger governance, and consistent enforcement—combined with active institutional investors and coordinated policy—are essential to rebuild trust. The shared vision is a fairer, more resilient market that attracts durable capital and restores Thailand's competitiveness in the region.

Structural Challenges Behind Rising DebtThailand's household debt has become a deep structural challenge. While total outstanding debt stands at about Bt3.5 trillion and has recently plateaued, this stabilization reflects debt deleveraging rather than stronger income growth. NPLs remain elevated at \(9.1\%\) or Bt1.2 trillion, concentrated in personal loans and auto loans, with housing NPLs also increasing. If informal debt is included—estimated at \(14\%\) of GDP—Thailand's household debt could exceed \(100\%\) of GDP. The panelists agreed that the root causes lie in (1) low financial literacy, (2) weak information transparency, (3) the large share of informal workers who cannot access formal credit, (4) inadequate social safety nets (e.g., high medical costs driving informal borrowing), and most importantly, (5) slowing income growth, which prevents households from servicing their debt.

The composition of debt highlights mounting risks, especially among younger workers, and many still carrying obligations into retirement. Around half of those aged 22- 29 have already been indebted, and one- quarter faces repayment difficulties. Importantly, most of this debt is consumption- based rather than business- related, making it harder to generate productive returns. The debt structure is dominated by housing loans (38%) and rising personal loans (20%). However, while mortgages still account for the largest share, the faster growth in personal loans and credit cards is more concerning because they are unsecured. Meanwhile, nano- finance is expanding, with more borrowers entering the system, but typically at smaller loan amounts, pointing to a widening but riskier credit base.

Addressing household debt requires both short- term and long- term strategies, as interest rate cuts alone cannot solve the problem. In the near term, the panelists discussed that targeted measures such as expanding the capacity of asset management companies (AMCs), offering soft loans, and providing regulatory flexibility can help restructure distressed debt. Strengthening data use through the National Credit Bureau and open banking initiatives is also crucial to integrate informal borrowers into the formal system.

In the longer term, structural reforms must focus on raising household income and competitiveness, while ensuring fairer and more inclusive credit practices across banks, Specialized Financial Institutions Supervision (SFIs), co- ops, and non- banks. Policymakers such as the Bank of Thailand, National Credit Bureau (NCB), and industry leaders emphasize three pillars: (1) stronger welfare support, including the planned negative income tax by 2027, (2) enhanced financial data systems for early warning, risk management, and broader access, and (3) productivity and income growth as the ultimate solution to reduce household indebtedness sustainably.

Although recent arrivals have softened, Thailand remains a key tourism destination, particularly from Japan, Korea, India, and Singapore. The market is now looking to China's potential recovery during the high season later this year as a critical swing factor. Trends such as Wellness tourism and Natural & Cultural attractions continue to show positive momentum.

On sustainability, most travelers express strong interest, almost \(90\%\) of travelers, but are not yet willing to pay a meaningful premium, contrary to what many assume. The more viable approach for the industry is to adopt sustainability measures that reduce operating costs—for example, optimizing flight operations and route networks to better match demand for airline operators. Moreover, initiatives that invite tourists to actively participate in sustainability projects tend to receive higher engagement than price- based approaches. Programs such as donation- linked activities, with businesses providing equal support, are more effective than attempting to pass costs through via higher pricing.

Key opportunities and risks were candidly addressed. Direct long- haul capacity to Thailand remains important for tourism growth. Geopolitical tensions—especially recent Thailand- Cambodia border issues—are disrupting logistics and sentiment, while safety perceptions affect Chinese arrivals. Policy levers such as visa rules, infrastructure beyond major hubs, and visible stability were emphasized to support sustainable, higher- value growth across the country.

Thailand's healthcare system is strong but now faces rising non- communicable diseases, an ageing population, higher costs, staff constraints after COVID, and tougher competition for medical tourism market. The key question was whether health tech, AI, and advanced therapeutics can be the next S- curve for the sector.

The panel featured a hospital executive, a deep- tech investor, and a senior academic from Siriraj Hospital. They discussed what is working today and what must change to move ideas from labs into everyday care.
Thai medical staff combine high competency with genuine compassion. This service culture supports safe and fast adoption of new tools.

Two waves stand out: AI across care pathways, and advanced therapy medicinal products (cell and gene therapies). Speakers also noted that discovery and development cycles are getting faster, making it possible to move new molecules to clinical trials much sooner than before.

Siriraj began its medical AI journey 5- 7 years ago with a Thai startup partner. Its radiology AI has been trained on over a million samples, reports accuracy above \(90\%\) , is on the Thai innovation list process, and has been licensed to leading private hospital groups. New focus areas include breast imaging, CT brain- bleed detection, pathology subtyping, clinical decision support, and ambient scribing that feeds structured data into hospital records.
A mobile stroke unit brings a CT scanner to patients, transmits images from the field, and starts treatment earlier helping overcome traffic delays. The model is expanding to more hospitals.
In genomics and multi- omics, Siriraj uses long- read sequencing (e.g., Oxford Nanopore) to support cancer, infection, and drug- allergy services, including a "drug allergy passport".

For cell and gene therapy, Siriraj is advancing from second- and third- generation CAR- T cell to next- generation fourth- and fifth- generation therapies. Current commercial therapies are very costly, so local capability is seen as essential to improve access and manage toxicity and efficacy for Thai patients.

A major hospital group said it will invest in Thai health- tech startups and be a first adopter across its network, emphasizing real- world deployment alongside returns. The goal is to speed translation from bench to bedside and keep breakthrough therapies financially sustainable in Thailand.

Barriers differ by origin. Foreign startups struggle with local regulations, finding partners, and commercialization bottlenecks. Thai startups face limited early- stage funding, less regulatory experience, and a lack of proven track record.

The panel proposed a "health innovation sandbox" to enable safe, fast testing and real- world pilots. They also called for stronger incubators and accelerators, clearer technology- transfer playbooks in universities, and closer ties to global hubs so Thai teams can learn and scale faster. Speakers noted that regulators and the universal coverage system can move quickly when value is clear.
Thailand has the clinicians, growing research depth, and hospital networks to lead in AI and advanced therapeutics if translation and scaling improve.

Priority actions are to build the national sandbox, fund mid- Technology Readiness Level (TRL) gaps, adopt early in hospitals, and strengthen university tech- transfer rules. The private and public sectors should act together, focusing not only on profit, to turn today's strengths into the next S- curve for Thai healthcare.

Thailand is preparing to launch virtual banks with the goal of expanding financial inclusion and modernizing banking models. While mobile banking usage is already high, many people remain underserved — especially gig workers, small merchants, and individuals without payslips or credit histories.

Examples such as Kakao Bank in South Korea and WeBank in China highlight that profitability is possible, but only with strict cost control. Thai virtual banks aim to be Alnative and cloud- native, offering simple, personalized user experiences while targeting a much lower cost- to- income ratio than traditional banks.

Trust will be built gradually through regulatory oversight, transparent products, and humanized digital support. Data- driven credit scoring will allow small, responsible loans to underserved groups, expanding as customer behavior demonstrates reliability.

Virtual banks will focus first on lending to underserved segments rather than competing directly across all areas. They will operate independently with separate systems, cybersecurity, and compliance, while still leveraging expertise from parent groups. Clear regulatory guidance on risk- based pricing will be essential.

Initial capital commitments will start around 5 billion baht, rising to 10 billion. The ambition is to achieve stronger returns than traditional banks, which currently deliver low profitability. Virtual banks also have the potential to reduce household debt risks by bringing informal borrowers into the formal system.

Within five years, success will mean a trusted, low- cost, innovative banking experience. Some groups aspire to become Thailand's leading virtual banking platform, while others aim to be remembered as the first to give millions access to formal financial products. Shared goals include innovation, inclusion, trust, cost efficiency, and strong compliance.
Core resilient, outlook intact - Connectivity growth remains solid; no change in guidance since the \(+4 - 6\%\) upgrade already announced earlier.

Market strategy clarified - Post TRUE- DTAC merger, pricing environment looks rational. ADVANC signals it won't fight on price; market share will be defended through quality of network and customer experience, not discounting (so still no price war expected).

Beyond mobile & cost load - Expanding into cloud, retail, English Premier League (EPL) content and virtual bank. 2H25 costs to pick up from content/marketing and seasonality (marketing spend - \(3\%\) of rev). Virtual bank likely loss- making at first, aiming for breakeven in years 3- 4.

CPN guided that it has already secured occupancy rate for Central Project project at \(90\%\) for retail while office prelease has already reached \(60\%\) with a target to reach \(80\%\) by the end of this year. The rental rate is guided to be lower than that of Central World given rent promotional discount for the new project. Rental rate could be higher going forward during lease renewal.

For July performance, the company guided for higher tenant sales from that in 1H (+3- \(5\%\) ). CPN sees higher spending from tourist malls. It also expects renovated stores to yield higher rent given uplift in tenant profiles.
They will focus on shareholders by maintaining ROE to be at mid- teens level. This would include growing operations, paying higher dividend.

OR remained cautious about the oil marketing outlook, expecting it to be range- bound in the intermediate term. Despite a low oil price outlook, it believes that government intervention remains a risk.

Oil retail industry growth should be anemic at \(1\%\) while it plans to grow by \(3\%\) , implying a market share gain of \(1 - 2\%\) . Pricing discount strategy has been discontinued but the company will use a non- pricing strategy to gain share instead. Lifestyle EBITDA margin is expected to stay flat at \(29\%\) . Coffee premium strategy is introduced to offset cost inflation. OR expects industry volume growth for coffee consumption to remain strong at \(8\%\) , implying robust volume growth for Amazon cups sold.
Capital allocation policy remains unchanged. This implies limited upside to its dividend payment.

Strategic growth 2025 - Growth from VGI synergy (media, PP), \(50\%\) Hello Bangkok acquisition, and consolidation of OOH market share \((- 70 - 80\%\) after adding Hello, Aqua, MACO). There is no rush to further convert static to digital as the current mix seems optimal.
Events & engagement - Muay Thai attendance projected at - 500k in 2025 (vs. 300k in 2024), reinforcing experiential revenues.
Near- term caution - Q3 outlook challenging from weak consumer- product advertisers, which account for - 20- 25% of ads spend.
PTTGC is optimistic about China anti- involution and Korean asset monetization.
PTTGC's asset monetization will be announced in October with expected proceeds of Bt30bn which will be used for deleveraging.
There is no need for PTTGC to increase its capital to pave the way for new strategic partners, we believe.
PTTGC's risk of a credit rating downgrade is low. Key credit rating agencies have maintained their ratings, and their next review will be in April 2026.
The new strategic partners are supposed to strengthen its crude procurement, international product placement, and operations.
The Clean Fuel Project's (CFP) mechanical completion is expected in 2027, implying that there is a high chance of commercial operation date (COD) before 3Q28.

New timeline and new budget of CFP should be revealed in late October and we think it will be better than the current budget. The risk of a credit downgrade by Moody's seems low in our view with Thai Oil's (TOP) commitment regarding its asset monetization plan, support from PTT, and deleveraging execution. Maintain Buy

The company guided for 2H25 operations to improve HoH for both retail (BIGC) and nonretail operations. Big C Supercenter's (BIGC) operation should improve from completion of store renovations in late 3Q25 (and rationalization) and revamping assortment. Meanwhile, non- retail growth should come from the resumption of Nestle products. The company also expects to have higher rental income after renovation is completed.
Same- store sales is guided to bottom out from June with QTD same- store sales growth (SSSG) of negative low single digits despite the calendar effect (spirit festival).

The company guided QTD SSS of negative low teens largely from back- office (construction material sales) given rains and product shortage (guided SSSG of negative low teens). QTD SSS of end- users was negative high single- digits. The weakness was seen at stores in Bangkok (and vicinity) and the northeast while stores in other regions achieved flat SSS. Despite weak sales, the company is positive that it should be able to maintain gross margin at \(18\%\) (similar to that in 1H) given product mix and increase in product margin in every category.

The company aims to open 2- 3 large- scale stores in this year. The store expansion should continue as the company believes that modern trade penetration in the construction material industry remains low (20- 30%).
MEGA's management indicated that the worst is over as of 2Q25. The company's own- brand business continues to show strong momentum, achieving double- digit YoY volume

growth across markets: high single- digit growth in Thailand, \(20\%\) in Malaysia, and \(25\%\) in Cambodia. Contribution from own- brand products is expected to rise to \(70 - 75\%\) of total sales over the next few years (from \(60\%\) currently). MEGA plans to focus on key therapeutic categories including cardiovascular, neuro, diabetes, knee joint, and pain management. Meanwhile, contribution from generic drugs is projected to increase from \(40\%\) to \(60\%\) in the coming years.

The Myanmar distribution business has declined by \(- 70\%\) from its peak due to a deeply low base but is expected to normalize in 3Q25. Coupled with a stabilizing Thai baht quarter- to- date, MEGA expects 2H25 performance to improve over 1H25. Management also noted that every 1 baht depreciation of the baht against the US dollar could positively impact net profit by approximately \(4\%\) .

MEGA unveiled a five- year plan (2026- 2030) targeting to double top- line revenue by YE2030. The company remains committed to a high dividend payout, supported by a net- cash position, without factoring in any share repurchase program. Manufacturing rationalization is identified as a key long- term growth driver, including next phase expansion of plant facilities in Indonesia and potential greenfield plants in Vietnam and Myanmar, with commercial operations expected within 2- 3 years.

Management remains cautious on the overall health of the Thai economy, noting that conditions show little to no sign of improvement. The recovery in loans and profits during the second quarter of 2025 is attributed primarily to a rebound from the exceptionally low base in the previous quarter.

SAWAD continues to prioritize loan quality over aggressive portfolio expansion. Despite healthy underlying demand, management has adopted a conservative stance given the uncertain economic environment, including the decision to lower loan- to- value (LTV) ratios.

For 2025, management maintains guidance of \(5 - 10\%\) loan growth. Within this, hire purchase (HP) loan contracts are expected to contract more gradually, improving from a \(4 - 8\%\) decline previously to approximately a \(2\%\) decline. Looking ahead to 2026, the company has set a higher loan growth target of \(15\%\) year- on- year, supported by anticipated regulatory adjustments from the Bank of Thailand.
Although the number of loan accounts is expected to continue increasing in 2025, the average loan size will be smaller, partially offsetting the growth impact.

The company has implemented cost- control measures, with the majority of savings derived from a reduction in headcount. Artificial intelligence is being deployed to automate processes and replace certain roles, thereby improving efficiency and reducing operating expenses.

Management expects funding costs to decline, reaching the low- to- mid \(3\%\) range. Approximately THB 20,000 million in funding will be rolled over by the end of 2025, contributing to this improvement.

Our PO for ADVANC is revised up to Bt336 following our earnings upgrade, derived from the average of our DCF value and target EV/EBITDA fair value. Our updated DCF valuation is Bt360 (using an \(8\%\) WACC and a \(1.0\%\) terminal growth rate), while our EV/EBITDA fair value is Bt301 based on 2025E EBITDA and an unchanged 8.2x target multiple.

The downside risk stems from increased competition from rivals, which could pressure market share and profitability. The upside risk lies in the potential spectrum auction in late 2026 for the 3500MHz band
Our 12- month PO of Bt67 is based on the average of P/E (Bt63.8) and DCF valuations (Bt69.7).
We use \(17x\) PER, which is \(10\%\) discount to one standard deviation below the company's 12- year average P/E given slowdown in NPAT growth this year.

Meanwhile, for DCF, we apply multiple discount rates of \(7\% - 9\%\) , and a terminal growth rate of \(3\%\) , on our 30- year discounted cash flow. The discount rate is based on a risk- free rate of \(3\%\) and a risk premium of \(8\%\) , which is consistent with other Thai equities and beta used is 1.0x which is the company latest 2- year average.

Upside risks are lower- than- expected utility cost, better than expected tourist recovery and falling interest rate. Meanwhile, downside risks are slowdown in the economy and slower- than- expected tourists recovery.

Our Bt9.0 PO is an average of our P/E and EV/EBITDA fair value. Our PE fair value is Bt8.9. We use 33x PE and 2025E EPS in our PE fair value calculation. 33x PE is based on one standard deviation below mean P/E from 2023 to present (post Covid). Our EV/EBITDA fair value is Bt9.1. We use 8x EV/EBITDA and 2025E EBITDA in our EV/EBITDA fair value calculation. 8x EV/EBITDA is based on one standard deviation below mean EV/EBITDA from 2023 to present (post Covid).
Downside risk is the macro factor. If GDP growth is lower than expected, PLANB's revenue could be lower than our forecast, shareholder approval for new assets recently acquired.

Our PO is Bt28.0/share. It is based on the average of three valuation methods (P/E, P/B, and DCF). Our target P/E is 8.0x while P/B is at 0.8x (both of which use the low end of its historical trading range to reflect the GRM, chemical spread volatility, weak petrochemical spread outlook, and refinery & natural gas regulatory risk). For our valuation base year, we use 2026E. For our DCF valuation, we use a WACC of \(11.5\%\) with a zero terminal growth rate. The DCF is based on an average olefins cracker EBITDA of US \(48/ton\) , polymer EBITDA of US \(82/ton\) , and overall GIM of US \(56.5/bb\) .

The upside/downside risks to our PO are HDPE/LDPE/LLDPE prices (higher/lower), the availability of ethane supply, BPA/phenol/acetone spreads, and volatility (higher/lower) in gross refining margin. The sales volume decline manifested in 2022- 2023 suggests the existence of volume risk. PTTGC is also exposed to forex swings and regulatory risks (via its refinery unit and its ethane contract with PTT).

PTT Oil and Retail Business (XNINF)Our price objective (PO) of Bt16.1/share is based on an average of P/E, EV/EBITDA, and DCF methodologies (in line with the approach we use for oil retailers). We ascribe a target P/E of 12.7x on core 2025E EPS while our target EV/EBITDA is 8.2x on 2024E EBITDA. Both are the average of the global oil retail comp with a 15% discount, reflecting PTTOR's lower- than- peers non- oil exposure. Our DCF is based on WACC of 9.3%, a beta coefficient of 0.9, and zero terminal growth rate (which we think is appropriate given the long- term threat of EV proliferation). The average oil retail marketing margin and oil commercial margin are Bt1.01/liter and Bt1.0/liter respectively. The average oil retail volume sales is at 17,715 liters/year (15- CAGR of 2.6%). The effective tax rate is assumed at 20%.

The downside risks are rising geopolitical tensions with Cambodia (if it is prolonged) given PTTOR's high exposure to Cambodia, volatile oil retail and commercial margins, the adverse impact of the pandemic, the popularity of alternative fuels, and fuel efficiency improvement. The recurring risks of government intervention, potential antitrust and competition laws, and potential new laws and regulations represent regulatory risks while key license renewals, potential conflicts of interest, and reliance on PTT and its associates round out OR's business risks.

Thai Oil - L (TOIJF)Our price objective (PO) of Bt37.4 is based on the average of P/E, P/B, and DCF methodologies. We ascribe a target P/E of 5.5x to an average EPS of 2025 and 2026, and our target 2025E P/B is set at 0.6x. Both are at the low end of TOP's historical trading range during 2008- 2018, which we use as key valuation reference points, but we have applied a discount rate of 30% to reflect the heightened CFP execution risk, the extreme GRM volatility caused by the Russia/Ukraine war since 2022, and the re- manifestation of regulatory risk. Our DCF is based on WACC of 12.2% with zero terminal growth rate. Our GRM average is at US\(7.4/bbl versus cash operating cost of US\)2.1/bbl. The effective tax rate is at 20%.

The downside risks to our PO are volatile refining margins, availability of crude oil, the construction/ramp up risk of CFP, a potential cost overrun of CFP, regulatory risk from potential intervention by the government, legal risk in relation to the termination of CFP's EPC contractors, and sovereign/political uncertainty in Thailand.
